CAP:
I shall be able to tell you that when the boyage Is over*
It111 be over tomorrow morning; we should make Albany about five
in the morning.
What a pity we shall not be with you to celebrate your triumph.
Not be with us: how come? Aiming to Jump overboard?
^e are leaving the vessel at West Poiht to pay a visit to the
Military Academy*
Not on this voyage, you ain't*
What I
No, sir; not on this voyage.
But we must stop; we are extremely anxious to visit the American
Military Academy; we are from France.
I don't care If you're from Timbuctoo; this voyage, we're racing
the Constellatlma ain't putting in nowhere. You'll have to
alleviate your anxiety all the way back from Albany, if you want to.
Are you sure? Tocqueville: Come l let us speak to the captain.
Won't do no good.
It is always worth trying.
Not this time it ain't. Take my word for it. I'm the captain.
You'. Then who is directing the vessel?
Oh, the pilot and the quartermasters, and the rest of ttiem. Tell
you one thing, gentlemen, you have a very poor opinion of the
spirit and eagerness of the American character if you think
there is any power on earth that can detain a steamboat when she
is engaged in an important race.
Except the boiler vursting. (RUEFULLY)
Bight you are; or tearing her bottom out on a rock. Good night.
(FADE OFF) gentlemen. Lovely bunch of rockets going up on the
left bank there.
